forestr
  • Functions Index

Annual growth rates accross entire census or within groups.

Annual growth rates accross entire census or within groups.

growth(census1, census2, rounddown = FALSE, method = "I", stdev = FALSE,
  dbhunit = "mm", mindbh = 10, growthcol = "dbh", err.limit = 4,
  maxgrow = 75, split1 = NULL, split2 = NULL)

growth_df(census1, census2, rounddown = FALSE, method = "I",
  stdev = FALSE, dbhunit = "mm", mindbh = 10, growthcol = "dbh",
  err.limit = 4, maxgrow = 75, split1 = NULL)

Arguments

census1

The R Analytical Table for a single census, either tree or stem.
census2

The matching R Analytical Table for a later census.
rounddown

If TRUE, all dbh < 55 are rounded down to the nearest multiple of 5.
method

Use 'I' to calculate annual dbh increment: (dbh2 - dbh1)/time, or 'E' to calculate the relative growth rate (log(dbh2) - log(dbh1))/time.
stdev

Logical. Default (FALSE) returns confidence limits, otherwise returns the SD in growth rate per group.
dbhunit

'cm' or 'mm'.
mindbh

The minimum diameter above which the counts are done. Trees smaller than `mindbh` are excluded. If `NULL`, all living trees are included.
growthcol

defines how growth is measured, either 'dbh'or 'agb'(agb=biomass)
err.limit

A number. Numbers such as 10000 are high and will return all measures.
maxgrow

A number. Numbers such as 10000 are high and will return all measures.
split1

a vector of categories, one per individual
split2

another vector of categories, one per individual

Value

growth() retruns a list with components:

  • rate, the mean annualized growth rate per category selected, either dbh increment, or relative growth

  • N, the number of individuals included in the mean (not counting any excluded)

  • clim (or sd with stdev = TRUE), width of confidence interval; add this number to the mean rate to get upper confidence limit, substract to get lower

  • dbhmean, mean dbh in census 1 of individuals included

  • time, mean time interval in years

  • date1, mean date included individuals were measured in census 1, as julian object (R displays as date, but treats as integer)

  • date2, mean date in census 2.

Details

growth() also requires the columns status and stemID in order to determine which stems should have dbh change calculated.

See also

Other functions from http://ctfs.si.edu/Public/CTFSRPackage/: mortality

Other functions to compare two censuses: mortality

Examples

# Filtering only 200 trees to make the data small
few_trees <- sample(unique(bci12s6mini$tag), 200)
census1 <- subset(bci12s6mini, tag %in% few_trees)
census2 <- subset(bci12s7mini, tag %in% few_trees)

# Across entire dataset
growth(census1, census2)
#> $rate
#> [1] 1.229134
#> 
#> $N
#> [1] 78
#> 
#> $clim
#> [1] 0.6596669
#> 
#> $dbhmean
#> [1] 55.11538
#> 
#> $time
#> [1] 4.958739
#> 
#> $date1
#> [1] 16584.45
#> 
#> $date2
#> [1] 18395.63
#> 

# Within groups defined by one "splitting" variable
# Note warning if split variable has grups which dbh is full of NA
growth_metrics <- growth(census1, census2, split1 = census1$sp)
#> Warning: At least one split-group contains all `dbh` values equal to NA.
#>   * Consider removing those groups before running this function.
# View just a few species with `head()`
lapply(growth_metrics, head)
#> $rate
#>    acaldi    alibed    alsebl    beilpe    calolo    cassel 
#> 0.4020363        NA 1.2087700 1.0140873        NA 1.0329468 
#> 
#> $N
#> acaldi alibed alsebl beilpe calolo cassel 
#>      1      0      2      2      0      1 
#> 
#> $clim
#>   acaldi   alibed   alsebl   beilpe   calolo   cassel 
#>       NA       NA 5.200918 0.907424       NA       NA 
#> 
#> $dbhmean
#> acaldi alibed alsebl beilpe calolo cassel 
#>     11     NA     67    113     NA     33 
#> 
#> $time
#>   acaldi   alibed   alsebl   beilpe   calolo   cassel 
#> 4.974675       NA 4.956879 4.939083       NA 4.840520 
#> 
#> $date1
#>  acaldi  alibed  alsebl  beilpe  calolo  cassel 
#> 16625.0      NA 16612.0 16633.5      NA 16554.0 
#> 
#> $date2
#>  acaldi  alibed  alsebl  beilpe  calolo  cassel 
#> 18442.0      NA 18422.5 18437.5      NA 18322.0 
#> 

# Within groups defined by two "splitting" variables
# Also warnings here (one warning per problematic splitting variable)
split_by_two <- growth(census1, census2,
  split1 = census1$sp, split2 = census1$quadrat)
#> Warning: At least one split-group contains all `dbh` values equal to NA.
#>   * Consider removing those groups before running this function.
#> Warning: At least one split-group contains all `dbh` values equal to NA.
#>   * Consider removing those groups before running this function.
lapply(split_by_two, function(x) head(x[1:6]))
#> $rate
#> [1] NA NA NA NA NA NA
#> 
#> $N
#> [1] 0 0 0 0 0 0
#> 
#> $clim
#> [1] NA NA NA NA NA NA
#> 
#> $dbhmean
#> [1] NA NA NA NA NA NA
#> 
#> $time
#> [1] NA NA NA NA NA NA
#> 
#> $date1
#> [1] NA NA NA NA NA NA
#> 
#> $date2
#> [1] NA NA NA NA NA NA
#> 
str(split_by_two)
#> List of 7
#>  $ rate   : num [1:69, 1:184] NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA ...
#>   ..- attr(*, "dimnames")=List of 2
#>   .. ..$ : chr [1:69] "acaldi" "alibed" "alsebl" "beilpe" ...
#>   .. ..$ : chr [1:184] "0019" "0100" "0101" "0118" ...

#>   ..- attr(*, "dimnames")=List of 2
#>   .. ..$ : chr [1:69] "acaldi" "alibed" "alsebl" "beilpe" ...
#>   .. ..$ : chr [1:184] "0019" "0100" "0101" "0118" ...
#>  $ clim   : num [1:69, 1:184] NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA ...
#>   ..- attr(*, "dimnames")=List of 2
#>   .. ..$ : chr [1:69] "acaldi" "alibed" "alsebl" "beilpe" ...
#>   .. ..$ : chr [1:184] "0019" "0100" "0101" "0118" ...
#>  $ dbhmean: num [1:69, 1:184] NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA ...
#>   ..- attr(*, "dimnames")=List of 2
#>   .. ..$ : chr [1:69] "acaldi" "alibed" "alsebl" "beilpe" ...
#>   .. ..$ : chr [1:184] "0019" "0100" "0101" "0118" ...
#>  $ time   : num [1:69, 1:184] NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA ...
#>   ..- attr(*, "dimnames")=List of 2

#>   ..- attr(*, "dimnames")=List of 2
#>   .. ..$ : chr [1:69] "acaldi" "alibed" "alsebl" "beilpe" ...
#>   .. ..$ : chr [1:184] "0019" "0100" "0101" "0118" ...

#>   ..- attr(*, "dimnames")=List of 2

#>   .. ..$ : chr [1:184] "0019" "0100" "0101" "0118" ...

# Use other arguments carefully; read `?growth()`

# Calculate not annual growth rate but relative growth rate
growth(census1, census2, method = "E")
#> $rate
#> [1] 0.02281451
#> 
#> $N
#> [1] 78
#> 
#> $clim
#> [1] 0.00723472
#> 
#> $dbhmean
#> [1] 55.11538
#> 
#> $time
#> [1] 4.958739
#> 
#> $date1
#> [1] 16584.45
#> 
#> $date2
#> [1] 18395.63
#> 
# Return `sd` instead of `clim`
growth(census1, census2, stdev = TRUE)
#> $rate
#> [1] 1.229134
#> 
#> $N
#> [1] 78
#> 
#> $sd
#> [1] 2.926403
#> 
#> $dbhmean
#> [1] 55.11538
#> 
#> $time
#> [1] 4.958739
#> 
#> $date1
#> [1] 16584.45
#> 
#> $date2
#> [1] 18395.63
#> 
# Include all living trees
growth(census1, census2, mindbh = NULL)
#> $rate
#> [1] 1.229134
#> 
#> $N
#> [1] 78
#> 
#> $clim
#> [1] 0.6596669
#> 
#> $dbhmean
#> [1] 55.11538
#> 
#> $time
#> [1] 4.958739
#> 
#> $date1
#> [1] 16584.45
#> 
#> $date2
#> [1] 18395.63
#> 
# Measure growth not based on `dbh` but on `agb`
growth(census1, census2, growthcol = "agb")
#> $rate
#> [1] 0.00332635
#> 
#> $N
#> [1] 78
#> 
#> $clim
#> [1] 0.00374775
#> 
#> $dbhmean
#> [1] 55.11538
#> 
#> $time
#> [1] 4.958739
#> 
#> $date1
#> [1] 16584.45
#> 
#> $date2
#> [1] 18395.63
#>
